tool_calls.name: create_workunit

arguments.name: Implement User Notifications for Workunit Updates
arguments.problem_statement: Currently, users have no automated way to stay informed about updates to workunits they are involved in (e.g., assigned tasks, status changes, new comments). This leads to missed deadlines, duplicated effort, and reduced collaboration efficiency. We need a robust notification system that delivers timely, relevant alerts via preferred channels (in-app, email) based on user preferences and context.
arguments.success_criteria:
1. Users receive notifications for key workunit events: creation, status change, task assignment, new comments, due date approaching (24h), completion.
2. Notification delivery is reliable (>99% success rate) with retry logic and logging.
3. Users can customize notification preferences per channel (in-app, email) and event type.
4. System handles high volume (10k+ notifications/day) without degradation.
5. Audit log records all sent notifications for compliance and debugging.
6. Notification system is integrated into existing workunit update workflows with <1s latency.
arguments.description: This workunit covers the full implementation of a user notification system for workunit updates. The system will support multiple event types, delivery channels (in-app and email), user preference management, rate limiting, retry mechanisms, and audit logging. It must integrate seamlessly with existing workunit operations while maintaining high reliability and scalability.

arguments.title: Adopt WebSockets over polling for real-time notifications
arguments.content:
We have decided to use WebSockets instead of polling for the real-time notification feature. This decision was made after evaluating several approaches:

Tradeoffs considered:
1. WebSockets provide true real-time delivery with lower latency and reduced server load compared to polling
2. Polling would require frequent HTTP requests, increasing bandwidth usage and server overhead
3. WebSockets maintain a persistent connection, which requires more server resources per user but is more efficient for real-time updates
4. WebSockets may face challenges with firewalls, proxies, and some network infrastructure that may not handle long-lived connections well
5. Polling would be simpler to implement initially but would scale poorly as user count increases

We determined that WebSockets are the right choice because:
- Our notification system requires near real-time delivery (success criteria specifies <1s latency)
- We expect high volume (10k+ notifications/day), where polling would create excessive HTTP overhead
- Modern browsers and servers have excellent WebSocket support
- The persistent connection model aligns with our user engagement patterns

Implementation considerations:
- Implement connection heartbeat/keep-alive mechanisms
- Add reconnection logic for dropped connections
- Consider fallback to Server-Sent Events (SSE) if WebSocket handshake fails
- Monitor connection counts and implement load balancing strategies
